THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan  for  the  COVID-19  Active  Response  and  Expenditure  Support 
(CARES)  Program  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  COVID-19  pandemic  response 
option (CPRO).1 
 
2. 
The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and the economic shock triggered by the pandemic 
are dramatically reducing the employment, income, and well-being of Uzbekistan’s citizens. Since 
16 March 2020, wide-ranging social distancing and containment measures have been instituted—
including  the  suspension  of  all  international  and  domestic  travel,  the  closure  of  nonessential 
businesses  and  educational  institutions,  and  compulsory  work  from  home  for  nonessential 
services. 2 These  measures  have  negatively  affected  the  economy,  with  real  gross  domestic 
product (GDP) growth dropping to 1.5% in 2020 from a forecast of 6% before the pandemic.3 The 
downturn  in  global  trade  and  lower  demand  and  prices  for  commodity  exports  will  widen  the 
current account deficit to 9.6% of GDP in 2020 from an earlier forecast of 4.7%. The nationwide 
lockdown  has  led  to  80%  of  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  suspending  their 
activities. About $700 million of tourism revenues will be lost in 2020. The expected 40% decline 
in remittance inflows in 2020 will adversely impact the low-income families. The unemployment 
rate is projected to rise to 16.5% in 2020 from 9.4% in 2019. An additional 448,000 people are 
expected to fall into poverty. The widening of the fiscal deficit to 5.6% of GDP in 2020 (from an 
earlier forecast of 2.7%) has increased the urgent near-term financing needs. 
 
3. 
The program will provide critical budget support to enable the government to undertake 
countercyclical expenditures to (i) strengthen the health system capacity to combat the spread of 
COVID-19; (ii) support businesses, employment, and job-creating regional public works; and (iii) 
expand  social  safety  nets.  Uzbekistan  meets  all  the  criteria  required  to  access  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  CPRO  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility,  including  robust 
macroeconomic management, undertaking of key structural reforms, a pro-poor countercyclical 
expenditure  program,  and  public  debt  levels  maintained  at  sustainable  levels  (Table  1).4 The 
program is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 (para. 21).5

unemployment, leading to reduced incomes and even social distress.

sources fell by 38% in April 2020 against March 2020, with a decline of 46% in urban areas and 
37% in rural areas. Declines in income have been largest among the self-employed (67%). The 
share  of  people  unable  to  afford  their  basic  needs  was  12%,  and  people  reporting  reduced 
household food consumption reached 26% in April 2020. Women’s job prospects will be severely 
affected  since they  comprise  about  45%  of formal  employees.  Their  share in SME employees 
reached 22.5% in 2016. In 2017, 43.2% of SMEs were managed and/or owned by women, with 
one-third of new businesses registered by women entrepreneurs.25 The pandemic has wiped out 
tourism and high-value horticulture exports, which affect women as they comprise 54% of workers 
in catering and trade and tourism, and 46% in agriculture and forestry.

78% of formal and informal sector jobs combined. Over 80,000 enterprises in food catering, retail trade, services and 
transportation have stopped operating due to social distancing measures introduced in March 2020. Uzbekistan’s real 
GDP growth is, therefore, projected to drop to 1.5% in 2020, from the initial forecast of 6% before the pandemic. The 
projected sectoral growth at constant factor prices in industry will drop from 8.9% in 2019 to 2.1% in 2020, and services 
from 5.5% in 2019 to 0.6% in 2020 while the growth in agriculture will remain stable at 2.6% in 2020 against 2.5% 
growth in 2019. The real growth of private final consumption is projected to decline to 0.3% in 2020, against the pre-
COVID-19 growth estimate of 10.4%. The real growth of gross fixed capital formation is projected to decline to 4.5% 
in  2020  against  the  pre-COVID-19  growth  estimate  of  8%.  GDP  per  capita  was  expected  to  grow  by  14.5%  from 
$1,742  in 2019 to  $1,995  in 2020 under pre-COVID-19 estimates. The revised  projections  indicate that per capita 
GDP will grow by only 3% to reach $1,795. The economic shock has dramatically reduced the employment, incomes, 
and wellbeing of citizens. The unemployment rate is projected to rise to 16.5% in 2020 from 9.4% in 2019 with layoffs 
and returning migrant workers. The median household incomes have declined by 38% in April 2020 (46% in urban 
areas and  by 37% in rural  and semi-urban areas). Income  losses  in the  urban sector resulting from the  lockdown 
measures have spillover effects on rural incomes and on the informal sector, thereby worsening the poverty situation. 
The fiscal deficit  is projected to  widen to 5.6%  of GDP ($3.41  billion) against the  pre-COVID-19  estimate of  2.7% 
($1.86 billion) for 2020. Budget revenues are expected to fall to 25.2% of GDP in 2020 compared to 28.6% of GDP in 
2019, driven by fall in taxes. The pandemic is putting fiscal pressure on the government with the larger budget deficits 
expected in the second quarter of 2020, depending on the speed and breadth of disease spread. The government 
decided to lift its cap of $4 billion in total foreign borrowings to finance the pandemic response. The government plans 
to borrow from IFIs to finance the fiscal deficit. The uncertainty in the financial markets is constraining the liquidity 
options for the government, which just debuted with its Eurobonds in 2019. The sum depreciated by 6.7% against the 
United States dollar from 1 January 2020 to 15 April 2020 and it has been stable since mid-April. The CBU lowered 
its benchmark interest rate from 16% to 15%. 
The government laid out a comprehensive set of health, economic stabilization, and social protection measures under 
the  Presidential  Decrees  No.  5969,  No.  5978  and  No.5996  and  established  the  ACF  of  SUM10  trillion  under  the 
budget.  These  measures  constitute  the  government’s  COVID-19  pandemic  response  plan.  Main  health  measures 
comprise  (i)  improving  the  capacity  and  preparedness  of  sanitary-epidemiological  units,  hospitals  and  quarantine 
complexes; (ii) addressing shortages in testing systems; (iii) procuring protective and diagnostic equipment, and (iv) 
providing  salary  supplements  in  the  form  of  hazard  pay  for  medical  staff,  directly  affected  by  COVID-19.  Main 
economic  stabilization  measures  comprise  (i)  supporting  affected  businesses,  including  tourism,  transport,  and 
services through various tax incentives and loan deferments and (ii) creating jobs through public works in the regions.

These measures are supplemented  by monetary measures aimed at  increasing  access to finance for businesses, 
particularly SMEs. Main social protection measures, targeting the poor and vulnerable groups, comprise (i) expanding 
social  assistance  programs  for  low-income  households  receiving  childcare  benefits  and  increasing  the  number  of 
households  qualifying  for  social  benefits;  (ii)  paying  salaries  of  public  sector  workers  (i.e.  teachers)  and  providing 
temporary  disability  benefits  to  quarantined  workers;  and  (iii)  expanding  paid  leave  and  work  from  home 
arrangements. The government’s response has strong gender and social protection elements to preserve the health, 
incomes  and  livelihood  of  women,  children  and  low-income  households.  It  supports  delivery  of  critical  medical 
equipment for health workers, of which 80% are women. The incentives for businesses will benefit the women owned 
and/or managed SMEs, which constitute 43% of SMEs. Small-scale regional public works will target employment of 
members of low-income households. The number of low-income households receiving childcare and social benefits 
will be increased by at least 10% in 2020, prioritizing single mothers, divorced women and widows. Furthermore, with 
the eligibility criteria for social benefits simplified and the income criterion relaxed, the total number of households 
receiving  social  and  childcare  benefits  will  reach  843,000  compared  to  595,400  before  the  pandemic.  Temporary 
disability benefits will be provided to quarantined parents and individuals caring for children. Salaries of 1.04 million 
schoolteachers, of whom 70% are women, will continue to be paid. 
Uzbekistan has a strong record of sound macroeconomic management. The economy expanded by 6.8% on average 
during 2010–2019. Uzbekistan has embarked on structural macroeconomic reforms in 2017, including liberalization 
of foreign exchange, governance reforms for SOEs, and tax reforms to move away from a development model built 
on import-substitution and SOEs to one based on private sector-driven market-economy and to open the country to 
international markets. Uzbekistan has achieved 5.6% GDP growth in 2019, driven by (i) real growth in industry (8.9%) 
and services (5.5%), (ii) growth in gross fixed capital formation (46%) and private consumption (6.3%), (iii) remittance 
inflows, (iv) economic diversification with rising private sector participation, (v) growth in merchandise exports (22.1%) 
driven  by  international  demand  and  high  global  prices  for  its  export  products  (natural  gas,  cotton  and  non-ferrous 
metals), and (vi) foreign investment, including financing from the international financial institutions. Historically, the 
country has pursued a conservative fiscal and debt policy with official foreign exchange reserves standing at $29.2 
billion (equivalent to 14 months of imports), external debt at 43.5% of GDP, and public debt at 29.2% of GDP in 2019. 
However, recent structural reforms have led to widening of the fiscal deficit from 1.9% of GDP in 2017 to 3.9% of GDP 
in 2019, reflecting the increasing social spending to mitigate the impact of the structural reforms. Devaluation of the 
currency by 48% in 2017, price liberalization and growth in bank credit (103.8% in 2017 and 51.3% in 2018) led to 
rising inflation from 8.8% in 2016 to 17.5% in 2018. With CBU’s inflation targeting regime and government’s policy of 
reducing directed lending to SOEs, inflation slowed to 14.5% in 2019. CBU aims to bring inflation below 10% by 2021 
and 5% by 2023.The national poverty rate has been declining from 25.8% in 2005 to 11.4% in 2018, reflecting rising 
share of SMEs, remittance inflows, regular public wage increases, and targeted social safety nets.   
The government implemented a robust response to control the spread of the COVID-19 and provide urgent medical 
support  to  affected  population.  The  government  has  collaborated  closely  with  the  WHO,  agencies  of  the  United 
Nations  and  international  development  partners,  including  ADB  to  strengthen  the  health  response  and  mobilize 
support  for  the  COVID-19  response.  The  government  took  early  preventive  steps  since  end-January  2020  and 
established  the Special Republican Commission,  headed by the  Prime Minister. When the  first COVID-19  positive 
case was confirmed on 15 March 2020, the government took proactive measures to prevent the nationwide spread of

as several countries bilaterally have provided technical and financial assistance for procurement of critical medical 
equipment and supplies, capacity building of medical staff and expanding social support systems. To undertake health-

SUM1 trillion (about $104.6 million) from the ACF. Of that amount, as of 15 April 2020, over SUM226 billion has been

private  sector  development  and  achieving  inclusive  and  sustainable  economic  growth  with  poverty  reduction.  The 
government remains committed to implementation of other ongoing structural reforms on macroeconomic and public 
financial management to improve the effectiveness of the countercyclical response. 
The debt sustainability analysis conducted by ADB in April 2020 showed that Uzbekistan’s debt levels are sustainable.
